reviewText:
This is actually not a bad game.  It's much better than the predecessor 'X-Blades' which isn't even worth your time.  That's not to say it doesn't have flaws, but overall I had fun with it, and it kept my interest long enough to play through it twice.

Gameplay is pretty standard hack n slash fare, with two attack buttons and a variety of magical skills you can use fluidly along with your swords.  You also carry a gun you can whip out at any time if you like, and while the third-person shooting may not be as advanced as something like Gears of War, it works and it's easy to use.  There's also an interesting time control mechanic where you can rewind time and fight alongside past versions of yourself.  You'll also use this ability to solve puzzles, although none of them are terribly difficult.

There isn't a lot of variety in the enemies, but mowing down hordes of them is still good for some mindless action, and when they do change it up you'll have to adapt your approach accordingly.

The visuals are gorgeous in this game.  The sound design is excellent as well.  The characters however, are kind of shallow (the main character in particular is really annoying), and the story is pretty difficult to follow.  These things aren't the main focus of the game though: the gameplay is.  And the gameplay that is there is solid, and there are many unique game environments to make your way through.  All things considered, this is a pretty decent game.

This doesn't actually matter though since the real key here is the magic powers you gain throughout the game. It's not really the voice actors fault as most people say, but actually the script they were given to read.

You play Ayumi a treasure hunter so its natural you would be seeking treasure, but the games dialogue tends to beat you over the head with it so hard that it is really annoying. I mean your gaining magic powers and Ayumi remains conserned over treasure until the very end. With magic powers you don't need treasure would be a logical way of though along with why am I getting these powers?

The controls are pretty solid for the most part. The only real issue is the instances when you push the counter button and nothing happens. The enemies don't change a ton, but it wasn't bad either. The gunplay is actually very nicely done as well. The later levels add in a new type of gunplay which I've seen before in Darksiders where you get a powerful gun on the floor for certain fights which adds good variety.

The level design is fantastic. The puzzles aren't that challenging but they help mix up the gameplay. You go from a volcano to a winter scene and your characters clothing changes depending on where you are. The garden level of the skygods is probably the best looking, but the others don't lag to far behind.

The story itself is better then most people claim. The main issue is your characters lack of interest in it. The notes along the way really help flush it out as well. Everything gets put into place by the end of the game. The ending does solve a lot of problems but it also ampifies your characters lack of believable emotion.

Overall it's a fun game and I would almost say it is criminally under rated by the mainstreem review websites. I'm not saying you'll play it more then once, but it's a great game to pick up for a few bucks.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I'm only 2 hours into the game so far (3rd 'world').

Blades of Time was something I picked up on a lark while it was on sale. The fact that it was from the people who made X-Blades (never played, but it looks really fanservicey) and checking a few reviews made it seem mediocre.

I was wrong. This game is wonderful.

Don't get me wrong, it is flawed. Graphics aren't great and the controls aren't as tight as you'd want in a 3rd person platform/hack and slash game but the core mechanics: adding powers to your character, the combat combo system, ranged combat and melee combat all feel great. The real shining point, however, is the time manipulation.

In games like Prince of Persia, you rewind time to recover from mistakes. Here, you rewind time, which locks you in place and rewinds everything ELSE in the world. Then, there are two copies of you running around. Your former self just continues to do whatever it was that you did at that time, and enemies AI kicks back in.

An example of this is if you wanted, you could copy yourself a bunch and all have them aim rifles, shooting at a tree. Then make a final copy which kites the bad guy over to where the shots are happening. It's unlikely that you'd need to do this, but it's possible!

Anyway if you see this game on sale, grab it. It's not going to push the boundries of PC gaming, gaming or even your expectations of games, but it will provide you a solid amount of *fun*.

reviewText:
While the dialogue is poorly executed (at least in English), the combat in Blades of Time offers enjoyable button mashing.  If you can keep track of which Prince of Persia or Devil May Cry entries may work on your computer then you'll probably want to purchase them instead, but this plays much better than Garshasp.  I'm curious to see how the previous telling, X-Blades, holds up.

Where Blades of Time seems to shine is in its Outbreak mode.  This is a MOBA variant which can be played either cooperatively or between teams.  There's a catalog of items/effects to earn and I appreciate having an entry in the genre with decent gamepad controls.  Unfortunately, there is little online competition despite some enthusiasm in the Steam forum.  There is, however, a single player mode where most of the same awards can be earned.  If my review sounds too vague, it's because I've been playing short sessions of this for so long I've forgotten the subtleties of the campaign.

Dumb story aside, Blades of Time's real cardinal sin is the placement of checkpoints before cutscenes instead of after.  There's a button to skip through them, but it's still annoying after a dozen deaths in a boss fight.

I wouldn't bother getting the Dismal Swamp DLC on its own.  The included mission removes character abilities in favor of allies to protect.  An Outbreak map might also be included, but if that's what you're after then you might as well get the Limited Edition for the Sky Islands one as well.

reviewText:
When I first started this game, I hated every character and loved the combat. I thought the story was incredibly stupid and I was kind of surprised a game like this even had a story. It's the kind of game where every female character looks like they just came out of a 14 year old boy's wet dream. Ayumi isn't even the worst offender of this!

Shockingly enough, the characters evolved such that I actually *liked* them- each main character received enough characterization to become real, likeable, *people*, rather than the walking videogame cliches they look like (ridiculously musclebound man, ridiculously over sexualized women). This astounded me; I was not expecting to have anything but contempt for the game's seemingly pathetic attempt at story. The main plot, too, evolves into something worthwhile. The biggest problem this game has is probably the fact that the story and characters are overwhelmingly generic for the first half of the game.... but it does metamorphose into something unique towards the end. Well, the characters do; the story is largely generic still but there are several key plot points that separate it from the rest.

Unfortunately what did not evolve over time was the combat. As far as I know there are no combos to learn besides the very limited set you start out with. One of the combos brings you up into the air as you swing your sword about wildly, *but there are never ever any enemies that will be in the air with you*. What ends up happening is a lengthy animation of you swinging your sword in the air for 5 seconds while all the enemies wait for you to return to the ground. This happens automatically when you jump and attack- so if you need to jump over to an enemy *quickly* and attack him, unless you're very careful you might accidentally start that useless combo and it will prevent you from doing time sensitive things (there is no way to stop once started). I feel like I missed out on a mechanic or two though- you can lock onto enemies and dash at them, but 90% of the time the game bugs out and the dash is in slow motion and you never even reach the enemy. Then I read something about hanging from enemies in midair and hitting them with your sword. Huh. The most I was ever able to do was slide off them like they were covered in motor oil. You gain the ability to use fire, ice and generic projectiles very early on and then (with one exception) from there on out, all upgrades are minor and passive (for example, you might gain the ability to do more damage by using fire on someone who is frozen. No expanded gameplay, just ways to optimize damage). I started out really loving the combat, but it gets very old very fast. And it's very buggy. The entire game is buggy actually. Luckily you can usually fix everything by reloading the last checkpoint, but if your checkpoint is before a particularly challenging battle, that can be frustrating.

Another major problem with this game is there are too many different mechanics. It feels like I'm playing a very long demo of hundreds of different games. Yes, the combat is boring, but constantly changing the rules of the world is not the way to fix that. At one point you gain wings and can fly, and I don't even think it is explained... then you lose your wings shortly after, also unexplained. I found out by jumping off a cliff and falling to my death. At one point you are given a gun which you are required to use; if you kill the enemies without the gun, they keep regenerating indefinitely, and this is *not explained*. It was pretty obvious I had to use the gun to kill them, but I couldn't quite figure out how, and I couldn't proceed by killing them normally. The biggest problem was the stupid jump combo- you had to freeze the enemy with the gun, then drop the gun and hit them before they thawed, except I would always activate that useless combo and never get to them in time.
The time rewind itself is also problematic. For example, the ability is not explained at all. You are told that you have it, then you need to figure out how it works, which is a process that will take the rest of the game. But the game arbitrarily changes the way it works and often doesn't even let you use it! How can you learn to use it if it keeps alternating between different rule sets and often isn't even available to use? So far what I *think* happens with the standard set of rules is; any time clones of you will disappear if the main you alters enough variables in the past. So if you go back in time and get an enemy to follow the current you instead of the past you, the past you just disappears. Which is a problem because most of the time the point of time rewind is to distract enemies- but they mostly seem interested in *you*, not your past clones, which makes them all vanish, which makes the game frustrating. OK, so I understand that, I'll try to use it against this boss now that I'm a little better with it. Oh wait, you can't. Why? Because. Time rewind is not available to you for nearly *every single boss*. Then, some of the larger enemies require that you use it, but the way it works is completely different for those enemies. In one case- there's a quick time event which you need to do twice at the same time. Cool right? Not really. You do it once, you rewind time and if you don't press the button *immediately*, you lost your shot at it and you need to spend 5 more minutes weakening the enemy again. To reiterate- you can't just go back in time and wait for the opportunity to use the quick time event going forward in time, you have to hit the quick time event whilst going backwards in time.. because for some reason your clone disappears in this particular context (you can't make time rewind clones). Then, on the giant worm boss, you can make time rewind clones but the moment you do the boss just retreats, changing variables and erasing all your clones immediately. The logistics of this time rewind thing is complicated enough without all the arbitrary exceptions and changes.


I can't decide if I like this game or not. On the one hand, there are unique gameplay and story elements that are definitely worth experiencing; there is nothing else like it. On the other hand, the game doesn't respect itself enough to expand upon the more interesting elements and instead chooses to try 100 different things, which all collapse into one incoherent mess of a game. I suppose I recommend this game only because the length is short enough that you can actually complete it before being fed up with its many issues, and I think it is worth at least $10, so pick it up in the next sale.

reviewText:
It's crazy and quite challenging.  Even though I do recommend trying it out I have to say the game comes up short.  What I mean is that it has all the makings of a really amazing game but they just don't quite come through.

It has an awesome two-bladed brawling system with lots of options to mix up the combat, and a dashing system that allows you to move at incredible speeds, but there is no targeting system so it's easy to end up swinging or moving the wrong directions.

It has a third person shooter mode that allows you to break up the monotony of combat, but there is no cover system that allows you to take full advantage of this and switching between the combat modes is extremely frustrating.

The camera can be controlled, but if you are not actively controlling it then it wanders into the worst possible positions, and odds are that you don't have a free thumb to be manipulating it.

There's a decent story line that seems to be going on but it has no solid presentation to it, so we are stuck watching the conflicts between these various factions from one character's perspective and we hardly know what their motives even are.  All we really know is that Ayumi wants to get out of Dragonland (original) preferably with some treasure.  Everyone else just seems to want to kill you and that's all that seem relevant.

There is an upgrade system but it's largely unsatisfying.  Your basic skills remain largely the same you mostly just build on your magic.

The controls were not prioritized well and many functions just won't work at critical moments.  I almost think that the programmers thought that this should be the central idea for the final boss fight.  The game is challenging but some of the challenges feel like they went the whole wrong way.

There is some intense challenges in this game, but sometimes you'll just get stumped on what do, like when you encounter the Slasher on the Skydock.  You'll end up dead and then looking at the screen wondering where you went wrong.

In all, Blades of Time feels like a pretty good game with a REALLY AWESOME game trying to get out.  It mixes combat systems in a really cool way, but doesn't polish them to make them shine.  It gives us a story, but can't be bothered for good presentation.  It gives us controls that work except when it decides not to.  It give us puzzles and challenges with very little feedback on how things should be done.  In short, it needs a lot of work.
7/10.

reviewText:
TL:DR ‚Äì Third person hack and slash game similar to Darksiders, but very linear. There‚Äôs no significant backtracking, and all the puzzles are pretty easy to solve. You can beat the game in less than 10 hours. Technically, it has RPG elements but is extremely simplified.

In Blades of Time you play the treasure hunter Ayumi, a scantily clad, double sword wielding fighter who can kill a whole room full of armed men but can still occasionally act like Lara Croft in the Tomb Raider reboot (whiny and afraid). It‚Äôs hard to blame her though because after trying to crash her way into a mythical treasure trove, she and her sidekick Zero (a big buff dude) get thrown into Dragonland. Now separated from Zero, you (as Ayumi) need to find your way through the monster infested Dragonland back to your own world. No, Dragonland doesn‚Äôt have any dragons for you to fight, but there are a variety of creeps itching to take a bite out of all your exposed skin.

Gameplay wise, Blades of Time is a third person melee game where you can just mash the attack button and Ayumi will swing her swords like a ninja commando slashing everyone around her. However, unlike games such as Darksiders or Devil May Cry, the enemies aren‚Äôt really ‚Äústunned‚Äù by your hits and can still attack you even as they‚Äôre flinching from your strikes. Your attacks don‚Äôt interrupt them.  Fortunately you have a short range dash/dodge move that you can use to evade enemy attacks. One thing I noticed is that either the enemies all have a lot of health or your sword strikes are really weak, because killing enemies takes a lot more hits than you would expect.  Seriously, it takes like 20-30 hits to kill anything with your swords. You do have a rifle to shoot baddies with though, and that seems to be pretty strong.

I said before that the game is simplified, and this applies to character development and equipment. You don‚Äôt ‚Äúlevel up‚Äù in the game, and you don‚Äôt collect money to buy items with either. As you progress through the story, you ‚Äúfind‚Äù new skills or upgrades to your existing ones. They‚Äôre unmissable so don‚Äôt worry about not finding an awesome spell. All of your equipment upgrades are found using a homing compass that also guides you on which direction you should be traveling. The equipment is missable, but none of it is game changing. They all just boost 1 of your skills, and nothing else (no +armor or +damage). There are only a few magic spells for you to use (fire, ice, and a heavy blast) but they add a little variety to your gameplay. They‚Äôre not especially strong either though.

Probably your greatest tool (and the reason for the game‚Äôs title) is your ability to reverse time for a short period. During the time reversal, enemies and your past self will re-enact what happened a few seconds ago. During this window you can attack the enemy with your clone for a double or even triple attack (if you reverse time in the middle of another time reversal). This is also used for puzzle solving since there are some areas that you can‚Äôt progress without hitting 2 switches at the same time (stand on switch 1 and reverse time, then stand on switch 2 while your clone is still on switch 1).

Pros:
+Simple gameplay and no ‚Äúresearch‚Äù needed. Don‚Äôt worry about character building.
+The game runs smoothly despite having nice graphics for a fantasy world with magic and monsters. My computer didn‚Äôt even heat up very much.

Cons:
-If you‚Äôre looking for an in-depth RPG like Dragon age, or a loot game like Diablo, Blades of Time isn‚Äôt the game for you. Also, the game‚Äôs ‚Äúdialogue‚Äù is kind of weird. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs translated from another language or just badly written at times.
-There is this really annoying bug involving getting your spell casting ‚Äústuck‚Äù that requires a game restart to fix. It happens a lot in boss battles, and at first I didn‚Äôt even realize it was a bug. I thought I had a keyboard button jammed or something. It occurs when an enemy interrupts one of your magic spells.
-The Outbreak multiplayer option plays like a third person MOBA but there‚Äôs nobody playing online. Don‚Äôt get this game for the multiplayer.

Overall, the game is fun to spend a weekend on, especially if you just want brainless hack and slash without worrying about exploring huge areas or backtracking. You also get to fight large boss monsters and earn some easy Steam achievements. 7/10

reviewText:
I was positively surprised by this game. Whenever a female character is presented in a certain way, there is always the suspicion that the developers are trying to sell a game based on that presentation. While I dislike that cynical view, it isn't like it came from nothing, sadly.

That said, this game has some interesting combat mechanics, and overall, I found the combat fairly enjoyable. The most notable element is a sort of time-rewind mechanic, but the way this works is it leaves a clone of you that does whatever it was that you did up to the point you started rewinding time. They use this well in puzzles, and it adds quite a bit to combat, allow for you to unleash intense burst damage. There is also a sort of magic system that works very well for this sort of action game. Basically, attacking enemies builds up a meter that allows you to use magic at certain points. It also gives you an extra-health potion (essentially) when it overflows.

The story is OK, the dialog is often cringeworthy (though I felt it was more from the writing than the voice acting personally, others may feel differently, though). The locations are varied and interesting enough.

Also, for some reason, there is basically a MOBA mode, not unlike that random Guilty Gear MOBA. I have no idea why, and I find it most perplexing.

To recap:
+ Solid Combat
+ Interesting Time Mechanic
+ Nice Locations
= OK Plot
= Random MOBA mode?
- Bad Dialog

Visually, BoT is a huge step forward. Beautifully designed and detailed levels with vibrant colors in varying enviroments add a lot to the mood in the game.

While the game isn't exactly an AAA title, it offers a solid and challenging 9-10 hours of playtime for the main story. The Dismal Swamp DLC, in which you play from the point of view of one of the side characters, adds another hour of playtime on top of it.

Additionally, the game features a fun DOTA-style coop-/versus-mode where you face hoards of enemies and have to destroy your enemy's towers.

BoT offers a solid, challenging and fun experience, so make sure to give the demo a try!

reviewText:
This game is one of those hidden gems. It's not perfect but it's similar to playing a game like Soul Reaver, Darksiders, Castlevania or Devil May Cry. You play as Ayumi, a treasure hunter who is looking for the treasure of Dragonland. The only way to get to Dragonland is by using the Sphere owned by the secret Guild. So, Ayumi and her partner, Zero bash into the guild and use the sphere to force teleport to Dragonland. In Dragonland, you meet the Chaos Keeper Statues and the Dragon Spirit of Time and then the story begins.

I must say that this game is on the way towards improving itself, I think Gaijin Entertainment (Russian developer) & Konami can probably get better. It's a failed remake of X-blades but worth trying it on sale. ($3.99)

There is a major gamebreaking control bug in the last boss. It caused me to be unable to complete the game. Due to its severity, I had to change my vote to vote this game down.


PROS
1. Gun and Sword style fighting
It's exactly like playing the beat-them-up games.

2. Quick To Learn
It's super easy to pick up if you've played other beat-them-up games.

3. The Teleporter
Very nice design. I like the way you made it spin before teleportation.

4. Sunlight is Deadly
I like the idea. Not being able to fight in intense solar radiation.

5. Skyguards
Nice idea too.

6. Different Guns / Swords
Nice to know the inventory work differently.

7. The Time Warping
Also cool. Especially when you have to piece together a puzzle to kill a creature. I would have preferred more time powers instead of just rewind.

8. Rocket Launcher
A pity that you are forced to drop it whenever you jump. This is most ridiculous.

9. Executions
Love the way it's quickly executed, even in mid air or mid combat. There is a slight graphics twitch but it's acceptable.

10. Aerial Combat
I love the way you can dash to an enemy and slash him to bits.

11. Creativity
Floating corals? Dying Sun planet? Sky Island? Nice.

CONS
1. Lame Names
Dragonland? Blades of Time?

2. Exact Copy
It's just way too similar to the other beat them up games.
a. Speed Dash
b. Dash Grab
c. Air Dash
d. Range / Melee combo
e. Double Jump

At least, improve on them.

3. Bad Marketing
The team didn't advertise this game well when it was released.

4. Enemies are Carbon Copies
You will see the same enemy in the same Verne model over and over again. The only difference is the top hat. E.g. The mercenaries.

5. No Cities
No rest stops, no shops, just chop chop chop. No additional nuggets of information and lore.

6. Rocket Launcher
It drops when you jump or dash. It's a very silly balance mechanic to prevent you from carrying it over to another location.

7. Graphics
Pretty mediocre. Honestly, there is nothing interesting to look at.

8. Chaos Slasher
That's the Dahaka from Prince of Persia.

9. Floating Coral Grabs
They are the same as grabbing lights in Devil May Cry or Darksiders.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Special Attack Styles
Look at Alice (American McGee) for more details on how to design.

2. More Weapons
I've played the Darksider series and I think more weapons would increase the variety.

3. Flipover / Slide Under
The Prince of Persia series allows you to flip over an opponent. I think this would be a great addition to the movements Ayumi can do. A slide under in between the legs of an enemy would be great too.

4. Flying Gun Combat
Imagine raining rockets while flying or shooting while in the air like Devil May Cry. That would be pretty cool.

5. Co-op Tower Challenge
I think this could be in the next series. Perhaps, Blades of Time is pretty lame so you could make a new series with all the same mechanics.

6. Wall Run / Wall Hop / Wall grab / Wall Combat.
The usual.

7. Stealth Assasinations
Good to have but not compulsory.

8. Swimming
All that water, a bikini and no swimming? What a waste.

9. Complex Puzzles for Big Ticket Stuff
If you have a secret chest or a super boss, finding a hidden location or a complex puzzle would be great. For story progression, simple puzzles and locks.

'Blades of Time' packs a sexy heroine with lots of action and puzzles. The controls are a little weird at first but once you customize and get used to them there's a lot of exploring, fighting and gun play around the corner, the story unfolds pleasantly and the different landscapes are very beautiful to watch. Sounds confusing? Time travel always is, but despite it's complications it's definetly recommended for casual adventure gaming!

Multiplayer: It's a real shame you can't play with at least 4 players at the same time because the defense/attack principle with a base works really well.

Dismal Swamp DLC: Very short and not very challenging but still fun as it shifts the game's focus from puzzles and special abilities to simple hack and slash and shooting survival mode.

reviewText:
The campaign can be annoying. Not necessarily the bosses, because they all have a certain weakness that you must figure and exploit, usually with your Rewind Spell (just recall the name of the game) - What is annoying is that certain actions can be unresponsive at times; I died a lot while platforming through the gauntlet after you meet Michelle and leave the crashed ship.

The worst part in this game (besides the ending ‚Äì‚ÄúOh that (horrible thing) happened‚Ä¶ END.‚Äù) was leaving that ship: the way in which you do it, and characters' responses to it... I've seriously never felt more bad-weird (or bad-wrong (badong)) because of something in a video game than I did in that moment.

The direction detection when, say, attempting to counter enemy attacks, and especially when having to use the Sphere of Order to move the energy through the conduits to activate a Portal (O.o) - when combined with the (at times) otherwise clunky/stiff controls‚Ä¶ Platforming and fighting  can  become painful to go through (I shuddered at the thought of Hard mode, but your Powers carry over and by that time, you‚Äôll have a much better feel for the mechanics).
USE.A.CON.TROLL.ER. Be precise in pushing the stick in the correct direction; it‚Äôs as simple as that.
Regarding that Sphere of Order comment: A lot of the puzzles in the game, though (theoretically at least) logical and very demanding mentally ‚Äì I was reduced to spamming and ignorant trial-and-error until I passed them because I didn‚Äôt understand the logic, because the methods for manipulating the puzzles weren‚Äôt very, er, intuitive.

More often than not, the game recognizes its own shortcomings/bvllsh!t and has a generous auto-save function. There aren't even any load times to speak of when doing so; the worst part is when you auto-load into a segment that has characters talking (my buddy had all the voices muted, which is worth considering, though it‚Äôs the writing (I would guess the translation, actually) more than anything that is turrible).

So. For all the game's faults and lack of polish. I still recommend Blades of Time.

The universe in the game is too amazing to allow something like, er, mediocrity (incredibly good mediocrity) to discourage ‚Äì comparable to Kingdoms of Amalur in artistic style. What I mean by ‚Äúmediocrity‚Äù is, in terms of, er, game design/execution, it feels like an incredible indie title/a flop from a AAA studio; the combat is pretty good, the concepts and mechanics are interesting, the story is serviceable - the way it all comes together seems *meh*.
If someone has done/will do a Youtube series on it, you MIGHT be better off just checking that out...


- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -


Multiplayer... ‚ÄúOutbreak‚Äù is amazing; the main reason for my recommendation.
Third-person hack 'n' slash moba.


The statements:
I cannot get into moba's.
Hack 'n' slash's: nothing special.

The bad:
The form of moba present in BoT is incredibly watered down, to the point that any who play such games would probably take offense at Blades' attempt to meld the genre with third-person hack 'n' slash, and to leave it so barebones (relatively).
The unintuitive control schemes are glaring when Bosses/Champions spawn (pumping a Skyguard full with your rifle and then being unable to dodge appropriately because your character didn't put their gun away in time sucks)(adapt and figure the nuances - it‚Äôs not actually  solely  because of the game‚Äôs awkwardness).
Too few maps (even though one of the DLC‚Äôs added another map).

The good:
Incredibly fun and addicting - if I was to ever get into a moba, it would be because of the transition that BoT would have served. If you have a friend whom you‚Äôre trying to get into a moba, I would recommend both of y‚Äôall to play this game; to introduce them to the basic concepts of the genre while keeping the actual gameplay simple as a hack ‚Äòn‚Äô slash. You can even run the multiplayer solo and it's still incredible.

What's interesting is that any gear you acquire in the Campaign is carried over into Outbreak and vice versa (thus, there ARE duplicates and clearly superior gear, which could be seen as annoying). The maps look pretty big according to the minimap; at first you might be saddened at how little they are utilized. Treasure randomly spawns in the middle alleys - that is the reason for those alleys, totally neutral zones. Where the turrets spawn is random in the symmetrical maps; as the bigger maps, sometimes the turrets might spawn in the top-left quadrant, the next time in the bottom-right.


Linear Maps:
A desert in which the sun saps your health quickly, so you must fight in the shade.
A jungle that is very appropriately sized to accommodate the amount of turrets.

Symmetrical Maps:
A swamp in which the most difficult grunts reside.
A series of floating islands that allows you to ‚Äúpush‚Äù your opponent (in versus) off the map.
A mountain pass filled with lava that looks like something out of LotR.


You start the matches with your choice of three powers/passives (Fire or Frost, Heavy Strike and Rage Saving are the best). You gain experience (resets every match); whenever you die, you get to put those experience levels towards more powers.
I don't understand why you can't do so without dying; apparently, it's the game's way of consoling you upon your death.
Just as Treasure randomly spawns, Bosses do too; spawn rates for these *expletives* increases exponentially with each difficulty, as does their strength (playing as Michelle, I swear that I've been one-shotted several times because an Invisible Assassin touched me... wasn't even facing me, just touched me)(Ayumi is beast, Zero is a little too slow).

How the progression works:
You gain Runes from Treasure and from Match Bonuses. There are Challenges you complete to earn Medals.
Collections of Runes have passive effects (i.e. if you‚Äôre co-opping, whenever your partner opens a Chest, you also get a Rune); you complete Formulas with Medals ‚Äì Formulas grant new gear (which, also, usually just grant passive effects, though more combat-oriented).

=================================================
BEAR IN MIND that I got my copy for stupid cheap through Humble Bundle.
For the asking price? This game is really not worth it.

*****VERDICT:*****
A SIDEWAYS THUMB SKEWED UPWARD

reviewText:
It is hard to write a small review about a game that you are enjoying in some aspects but despising in others. I will keep it as short and simple as possible:

Pro:
-Gorgeous Environments, for the most part.
-An (also for the most part) decent voice acting in all available languages (japanese best tho.)
-Large Variety of Enemies with some fresh ideas
-Good Animations
-Nice Time Rewind Mechanic
-Actually fun puzzling
-A decent fighting system with awesome magic skills...


Con:
-...which sadly lacks ANY impact in normal swordfighting (not magic) due to horrible sound effects and just not really good audiovisual feedback. Seriously, for the most part it sounds like you would try to rub cardboard swords against a cardboard enemy. Often you can't tell if your attacks stagger an enemy or if he attacks back.
-The controls, while fluid for the most part, just infuriate sometimes. WHY does the character stop after a jump, so you have to wait a second to run on? That just doesn't fit the gameplay. Same with dashing.
-Some annoying glitches (rare though. I clipped through the ground twice, which is not gamebreaking but annoying.)
-Horrible, horrible...HORRIBLE cutscenes. The characters move and act like paper. The voice acting, like stated in pro, is alright though.
-While, like stated in pro, the environments and enemies are often enjoyable and lush, there are WAY too many muddy textures that should just not have been there. It really drags down the otherwise beautiful scenery.

In the end it is still recommendable if you can overlook the lacking impact of fighting and some of the above issues. It is still fun, and while you will often shake your head about issues, the game is still...just, fun. Simple fun that the issues won't take away - luckily.

Personal Score: 7,5/10

reviewText:
At present, these are only my first impressions, but I have to say that from what I've seen so far, this game is really quite enjoyable. I'd describe it as a cross between Bayonetta and Tomb Raider - it's a hack-n-slash by nature but it also has a third-person shooter element, and you can switch between these modes on the fly, which I find to be a really interesting addition - it allows for a unique take on both genre's formulas, and contrary to what you might think, in the midst of a fight flicking between the modes feels rather natural - it almost feels as if the game encourages you to use both in tandem to achieve your goal.

In hack and slashes of this game's type, combos tend to be both essential and, for a gamer like me, rather hard to pull off. Blades of Time remedies this a little - whereas in a game like Bayonetta the combos would be a ridiculous string of button presses, Blades of Time has relatively simple button combos, press one button to ready, press another to attack. In that sense I found myself enjoyng the game a lot more, because I didn't really need to worry about all the ridiculous combos I'd have to pull off - While a more hardcore hack-n'-slash fan might not find this appealing, I personally think it's a nice touch, making the game easy to jump in and out of without needing pinpoint-precise button presses.

I have but two criticisms of this game: First, the english voice acting is pretty bad, though this is remedied by simply switching the voice language to Japanese, and second, the story makes absolutely no sense - the game goes straight from the title screen into the opening cutscene without a shred of explanation as to what is going on. However, when you're in the thick of it, hacking and slashing and shooting and magicking enemies like there's no tomorrow, you honestly forget about these errors, because you're just having too much fun to really care.

Overall, despite its shortcomings, Blades of Time is a lot of fun, and an interesting fusion of the hack & slash and third-person shooter genres, and I'd reccommend this game if you were a fan of either genre. An underrated gem, this game has enough action to keep you entertained for a long time.

reviewText:
Great game.

Can easily stand up to genre kings like Devil May Cry. Fast fighting fun in a very pure, uncompromised and likeable way. A solid selection and variety of moves, an interesting time-rewind feature to overwhelm enemies with multiple copies of oneself and solve basic button-press puzzles, nicely designed enemies, varied, beautifully designed and memoreable levels, a great soundtrack, a not necessarily revolutionary but nevertheless somewhat interesting story (it needs time to build up, but when it does it takes pretty epic shapes), increasingly likeable characters, a pretty good voice acting and big numbers of lines. It runs fast and smooth, the controls are easy (I played with an XBOX controller) and I picked it up very cheaply in a bundle. For which I feel like a thief now. I think I'm gonna buy one or another copy for the full price just because it seems that this game is a severly underrated gem.

There is even an online versus mode as well as a mildly strategic single- and multiplayer co-op arena tower defense mode with leveling and item mechanics and stuff. In other games I would usually see such a multiplayer mode sceptical, but as the singleplayer portion of this game is already great enough I think this is pretty awesome to have. I played the co-op mode once with a Japanese and it worked (which is not self-evident in such games). I didn't notice severe lags or synchronisation issues despite the distance to the host. We (well, I at least) had a blast. I didn't understand all he said over his mic because I don't speak Japanese, but we ran over tons of monsters and my screen was all slash and boom and peng and pow.

A few platforming sections I died in more often than I probably had to because the double-jump from the protagonist is not the most precise. There are some platforming and trap-evading parts where someone else might get a little frustrated, but I got through okay and the checkpoints in this game seem pretty fair.

Also, the story and character relationships can be a little confusing. Some good thoughts went into it, that's for sure, there are lore hinches that I liked. In the end everything gets resolved fairly well, but in the middle the game sometimes lost me a bit. I don't know if that is because I didn't play the prequel X-Blades" (which I sure will too soon). But
recommended: it finds a satisfying and understandable end."

The mechanics are actually almost rock solid, jumps, attacks, everything reacts fine as it should there is almost as solid as God of war except for 1 little detail.

when you use your attacks to test them, or against the air, well, you notice that you are hitting air. The problem is that when you hit an enemy or object, or the wall, you feel exactly the same, squat, nada. You cant feel the power behind your blows. You hit an enemy, you see that you are hitting them, yet you dont feel it on your control (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYEebRNb0ag  Minute 20 as an example, when he breaks a crate, then he hits a large enemy 10-15 seconds later).

In any hack/slash buttonmash game, when you hit an enemy, there is a proper reaction, either a combo hitcounter, some reaction of pain of the enemy, maybe slower attacks from your part. i dont know, something. In this game you feel like you are slashing leaves every single time,.

even the old snes beat em ups got those things right. I could kept playing, the mechanics are solid enough, i could bear the voice acting, couldnt complain about the graphics neither or the frenetic camera (yeah, you can dash and the camera moves a bit violently) , its just that i felt that my mouseclicks were worthless. there is no epicness in this. It felt empty/weak.

For better understanding of what i am saying. Imagine you are playing street fighter. You get in CQC, you throw a fierce punch to your enemy in the face, you hitted him, you see his health bar going down, yet there was no proper animation, your fist just went trought his face, yet worse, since you didnt altered his animation he can actually counter, and you will see your character on the ground, less health, but you just never felt a thing.

So yes, small detail, game breaker for me. I wouldnt get this game unless it comes in a bundle or if its really cheap, less than 5 USD and i still would doubt it.

reviewText:
At it's core Blades of time is a hack & slash romp through a fantasy world. You play as Ayumi, a scantily clad treasure hunter who has been seperated from her team. As you search for them you will come across hundreds of creatures, monsters and humans all intent on ending your antics. Throughout your adventure you will gain various magical abilities and weapons which help you to despatch your foes.

The game looks pretty enough, although nothing special, and the sound effects are good to. Where the sound falls down is in the terrible voice acting, although I have heard worse.

The basic action is good enough, but the real problem here is that the game keeps throwing new things at you. This may seem like a good idea, after all variey is the spice of life, but the ideas just keep coming. It seems that the developers wanted the game to be all things to all men. Take a huge dose of God of War, mix in a bit of Tomb Raider, add some guns, blend in loads of magic, add slow motion and time rewing etc. The list goes on and on...

The action is punctuated by some puzzles here and there, but these are all fairly easy to work out and most require you to use the time rewind mechanic.

I think if some of the ideas were shelved and the game was a little more simple, then perhaps I could recommend it. As it is though it quickly becomes frustrating, there's just too much to worry about.

If you're in the mood for some good old fashion fast paced fighting, old school style with blades and guns, this game is definitely worth a shot. Fairly good looking visuals with great gameplay, easy to learn and master.

Multiplayer outbreak takes the idea of a MOBO and throws you into the action in third person mode, able to select multiple abilities and be able to upgrade them as you fight on in battle.

Get enough rage, and you can blast away with your abilities. Go in blades-a-blazing or take the action from a distance with various different weapons, each of which has their own buffs to increase the chaos and carnage you deal. Light vs darkness, chaos versus order.

Campaign mode takes you on an amazing adventure crossing paths with mechanical beast to broken ships to demons of darkness. Multiple unlockable skins for character and various different weapons to choose from as you progress. Blades of time is definitely a good game with balance for both guns and blades with awesome moves to go with it.

Overall, Blades of time is a well rounded action game, with easy to learn gameplay mechanics, responsive and easy to learn controls.

reviewText:
Very enjoyable. It does have it's downsides though.

Pros:
-Runs very well(for me at least, not that my system is too old). Rarely had any issues with bugs or graphical issues. Only real bug that comes to mind is for some reson when I start flying (either in skyland or at the end) it would really mess up my keybindings with the only way to fix it is to quit and resume from the main menu. It would cause my LMB to use 2 every time I got a skull for it. It was quite fun to watch myself spamming fire everywhere. But at the last boss when having the right spell was important it became a problem. I had to beat him while avoiding using my wings even once.

- Looks nice. It overall looks like it could be real. But it does have a bit of cartoonish in it. Overall very well done and polished.

- Gameplay is very smooth. Aside from the flight bug I had. Animations for everything feels right.

- Characters are mostly interesting. Ayumi can get annoying. But this is mainly the script and not the character herself. As a few people have stated in relation to the voice acting. The script could use some improvements. I really think it wouldn't be so bad if we didn't have everything explained by her every time something new game along. Although outside of Ayumi there isn't much involvementwith other characters.


Cons:
- It feels like everything is handed to you. If there is some secret path to progress in the game it will show you the way. You're even given a compass to show hidden tresure. As long as you peek at it every once in a while you will have no trouble finding everything. Assuming I didn't forget to look at it a few times. Getting real annoying listoning to the main character explain everything to me. I would like to figure it out myself sometimes.

- Combo's are limited. Usually in these types of games you find you buy tons of attack combo's. In this game it's mostly about spells. And they're hardly challanging to use. I don't fully call this a bad thing. Since in most of these types of games with a bunch of attack combo's you find one you like and use it for 95% of the game. I prefer this game's approach. But there's nothing really crafty about using the spells. Enemies are not really weak or strong to the elements you use. You just used them based on the effects/items you want. Closest it gets is a boss that has a shield that can only be broken by the right element.

- Enemy(bosses make this the most annoying) attacks can easily rotate if you dash around them. You can be attacking a boss. Dash behind him as he attacks, and his next swing will instantly turn to you. The boss should have to turn or have an attack in that direction. Closest game I know of to seek improvement examples from would be Vindictus. Easily one of my favorite hack and slash games. Which I would still play if my account didn't get hacked and I lost everything with Nexon unwilling to fix it.

- I never felt I needed/wanted to use my time powers in fights unless it was required. Biggest problem to me is that you can push the enemies around so your close's attacks becomes messed up.


Overall 8.5/10

I was never bored playing this game even though it's system is very simple and it felt like my hand was held through most of it. If they can improve the AI of enemies, make combo's more interesting and make exploring rewarding this game would easily be a 9.5 or 10 for me.

reviewText:
Blades of Time the successor to X-Blades and awful incomplete hack and slash that will amuse you for maybe 3 bosses before you realize how broken and unfinished the game is.
Back to BoT, similar to X-Blades it feels like an older game that doesn't exactly hold your hand and thrusts you out into the world of unknown.

You'll quicky catch on that there are no combos just button mashing and learning to dodge and abuse your time rewind ability.In this factor the game gets better as you progress and get amazingly cool abilities to fight off even more challenging monsters.I played on hardmode without realizing you could go to normal mode and didn't repeat a level more than 5 times because of the usually good check points.

The mechanics overall are good and you run into some fun, interesting, and also annoying puzzles.
They also have treasure chests throughout the levels that reward loot.Though I've only gotten a total of 2 swords through my entire first play through.One at the very beginning of the game from a chest, the other from the boss before the final boss.Considering there are a large amount of swords in the game it kind of makes you wonder.

This game is definitely not worth the retail price and you shouldn't buy it unless you find it on sale like I did for the ultimate edition($7.50)
By the time you start to get some really cool abilities and you figure out how to use your abilities properly you realize you're practically done with the game and that there are some unpatched bugs that make doing the final boss annoying as all hell due to his mechanics.Thankfully there is a work around.

Overall I give it a 5.9/10 for a time waster mainly because some of the mobs don't even have a mechanic other than to make your life a living hell.

Very enjoyable. It does have it's downsides though.

Pros:
-Runs very well(for me at least, not that my system is too old). Rarely had any issues with bugs or graphical issues. Only real bug that comes to mind is for some reson when I start flying (either in skyland or at the end) it would really mess up my keybindings with the only way to fix it is to quit and resume from the main menu. It would cause my LMB to use 2 every time I got a skull for it. It was quite fun to watch myself spamming fire everywhere. But at the last boss when having the right spell was important it became a problem. I had to beat him while avoiding using my wings even once.

- Looks nice. It overall looks like it could be real. But it does have a bit of cartoonish in it. Overall very well done and polished.

- Gameplay is very smooth. Aside from the flight bug I had. Animations for everything feels right.

- Characters are mostly interesting. Ayumi can get annoying. But this is mainly the script and not the character herself. As a few people have stated in relation to the voice acting. The script could use some improvements. I really think it wouldn't be so bad if we didn't have everything explained by her every time something new game along. Although outside of Ayumi there isn't much involvementwith other characters.


Cons:
- It feels like everything is handed to you. If there is some secret path to progress in the game it will show you the way. You're even given a compass to show hidden tresure. As long as you peek at it every once in a while you will have no trouble finding everything. Assuming I didn't forget to look at it a few times. Getting real annoying listoning to the main character explain everything to me. I would like to figure it out myself sometimes.

- Combo's are limited. Usually in these types of games you find you buy tons of attack combo's. In this game it's mostly about spells. And they're hardly challanging to use. I don't fully call this a bad thing. Since in most of these types of games with a bunch of attack combo's you find one you like and use it for 95% of the game. I prefer this game's approach. But there's nothing really crafty about using the spells. Enemies are not really weak or strong to the elements you use. You just used them based on the effects/items you want. Closest it gets is a boss that has a shield that can only be broken by the right element.

- Enemy(bosses make this the most annoying) attacks can easily rotate if you dash around them. You can be attacking a boss. Dash behind him as he attacks, and his next swing will instantly turn to you. The boss should have to turn or have an attack in that direction. Closest game I know of to seek improvement examples from would be Vindictus. Easily one of my favorite hack and slash games. Which I would still play if my account didn't get hacked and I lost everything with Nexon unwilling to fix it.

- I never felt I needed/wanted to use my time powers in fights unless it was required. Biggest problem to me is that you can push the enemies around so your close's attacks becomes messed up.


Overall 8.5/10

I was never bored playing this game even though it's system is very simple and it felt like my hand was held through most of it. If they can improve the AI of enemies, make combo's more interesting and make exploring rewarding this game would easily be a 9.5 or 10 for me.

reviewText:
Blades of Time is a nice 3rd person action game with some cool mechanics and it looks good to boost. The enviroments are nice and varied, the enemies less so, but fun to fight nonetheless.

Fighting is pretty standard, normal attacks, magic attacks, and even 3rd person shooting.
The most notable mechanic is time manipulation, and you can have some pretty cool fun with it, distracting enemies with shields with a clone while you sneak behind them where they're vulnerable, piling up on them with 3 of your clones shooting a minigun at one enemy, attacking them with swords on all sides. It's pretty fun. It's also used for solving puzzles. They're not exactly brain teasers, but serve a purpose to mix things up.

There are secrets to find, some items to collect, and a co-op mode that i haven't tried but that seems to be dead. Try it with a friend if you can.

Also, to my great surprise seeing as how rarely games support that, even some big name developers don't seem to grasp the concept - this game supports hybrid gamepad and mouse input. Your mouse isn't disabled if you use a gamepad. This is especially good for Steam controller users, and the game is a delight to play as a result of that because you have better precission while shooting and are not limited to analog speeds.

All in all, this is a great port, no issues whatsoever, and the devs actually understood how to program the game for a PC. It's amazing how big name studios tend to mess up ports, but a smaller studio makes a good job.

The colors are a bit washed up, i guess that's the aesthetic they were going for, i didn't care much for that, but you can fix it as you like with SweetFX easily though so no big deal.

The story starts interesting, then looses itself a bit from the middle to the end, but all in all it's ok. If you want a good story play some RPG's or something. The story here is adequate, nothing horrible, nothing impressive.

Very recommended. If you have doubts, get it on sale.

reviewText:
Blades of Time is a classic slasher game similar to Prince of Persia series in many ways, utilizing but not coping mostly all of its features - intriguing plotline, acrobatic tricks, dynamic battles with lots of unique enemies, possibility to reverse time to solve puzzles or to defeat mob hoards and tough bosses.

Game has quite predictable but decent storyline, beautiful locations and good overall graphics as well as proper animations for characters and ambient, lots of gameplay features, such as combos, guns and magic, simple RPG elements with possibility to use different gear with unique properties, long enough campaign and interesting ‚ÄòOutbreak mode‚Äô featuring dota-like gameplay but in the third person mode.

Fighting system much easier to learn and use then in other games, you don‚Äôt really need to focus on combos and ‚Äòperfect‚Äô attacks, missing few hits wont make current battle much harder or even impassable, but that doesn‚Äôt mean you can simply click whole game away. Each enemy need own strategy to deal with and bosses usually requires active usage of time rewind, temporal clones and lots of shooting, especially on hard difficulty.

Of cause Blades of Time fighting system not that advanced like in Castlevania or DMC but as for me its still much more enjoyable because it wont enrage you or cheaply delay progress every time you meet harder enemies. Moreover, local magic skills may be used nearly every second without boring grind of energy\mana like in other games, thus making whole gameplay colorful and entertaining when you really enjoy slicing‚Äôn‚Äôdicing enemies differently.

That‚Äôs why its quite weird to read negative reviews on game blaming its softcore battle system or non-AAA storyline. Just compare pricetags for Blades of Time and Castlevania for example (10‚Ç¨ and 30‚Ç¨ respectively) and titles itself then ask yourself what did you expected to get for such small price and from a game company for whom it was basically a debut RPG game.

The only real cons of this game is a quite dead multiplayer (still its easy to find people to play with or against via Steam community groups) and no possibility to cooperatively play story campaign, only team-up in Outbreak Mode. Quite sad because its clear that campaign levels and story itself ready to be played in coop mode, maybe game budget was too low or developers just preferred to focus on singleplayer.

Still, for a story driven game for just 10‚Ç¨\$ multiplayer looks more like a bonus then a mandatory feature. Thats why Im thumbing up Blade of Times and recommend this game to everybody who like hack‚Äôn‚Äôslash genre.
